title: System FAQ
description: Provides help on different components and their usage. Each entry (under properties) consists of a 'title' for the help title, 'content' for the body of the help, and the display 'context' for the help. Entries in 'context' can be deserialised into a tree structure, with the parent component being the first entry in the list and so on. Alternatively, the context list can capture a collection of different display contexts where the help might be relevant. It is left to the implementation to decide the best fit.

properties.title: What is a COPO profile?
properties.content:
A COPO profile is a collection of 'research objects' or components that form part of a research project or study. COPO currently provides templates for creating/describing the following components:
  • Datafiles
  • Samples
  • Submission
  • Publications
  • People
  • Annotations

properties.title: How do I create a profile?
properties.content:
Click on the button, and fill out and save the presented form.

Video demo

properties.title: How many profiles can I have in COPO?
properties.content: You can have as many profiles as needed to represent your research projects. For instance, you can create a profile to represent work done as part of a grant, a sub project within a project, or a PhD project.

properties.title: What is a profile component?
properties.content: A profile component is a research object that forms part of a research project or study. Each profile in COPO comes with templates for creating/describing instances of the  associated components (e.g., Datafiles wizards, Publications form).

properties.title: How do I create components within a profile?
properties.content:
To create a profile component:
  1. Navigate to the component page
  2. Use relevant controls to either trigger a component form or initiate a component wizard.

properties.title: How do I describe datafiles?
properties.content:
1. Select the datafiles to be described under the Inspect pane
  2. Click the Describe button
  3. The description wizard will be launched with the target files available for description

properties.title: What is a description bundle?
properties.content: A description bundle is a collection of datafiles with similar attributes, which can potentially be described together.

properties.title: How do I exit a description?
properties.content:
You can select to exit a description at any stage
  1. Click on the Exit Description button at the bottom of the wizard pane
  2. You will be prompted to confirm the requested action
  3. All previously entered description metadata will be saved for the future

properties.title: How do I discard a description metadata?
properties.content:
1. Select the target datafiles under the Inspect pane
  2. Click the [Un]Describe button
  3. Any associated description metadata with the target datafiles will be deleted, and the status flag beside the affected files should change to red.

properties.title: What file types can I upload to COPO?
properties.content:
Datafiles uploaded to COPO should potentially be suitable (conforming to formats) for submission to the supported repositories. Some of the popular file types/formats supported in COPO include:
  1. FASTQ to FASTA format (e.g., .fastq, .fastq.gz, .fasta)
  2. PDFs (i.e., .pdf)
  3. Image file formats (e.g., JPEG, PNG, GIF, BMP)

properties.title: How long can I keep my file in COPO?
properties.content:
COPO only brokers the submission of data to remote repositories, and is not equipped to act as a 'silo' for datafiles.

Datafiles uploaded to the system are held only for short periods of time (apprx. two weeks), pending deposition of same to remote repositories.

However, given that individual project needs or circumstances may differ considerably, we are more than happy to discuss ways to better support your specific data workflow.

properties.title: Describing samples
properties.content: To start descrbing your samples, click on the icon, and follow the steps presented by the wizard.

properties.title: Sample types
properties.content:
COPO currently supports and provides configurations for describing the following sample types:
  1. Simple samples are based on BioSamples. They are repository agnostic, and are better suited for describing samples in a generic manner or in contexts where the target repository isn't known a priori.
  2. Extended samples are based on the Investigation, Study and Assay (ISA) specifications, and are better tailored for describing samples that will subsequently become part of data submissions to repositories such as ENA and Metabolights.

properties.title: COPO submission
properties.content: A COPO submission component is an integral part of a COPO profile. The page provides information about all submissions created (conclusive or pending) within a profile.

properties.title: How do I create a submission entry?
properties.content: To create a submission entry, you have to first go through the process of datafile description (under the datafile component). A submission entry is created when the user completes the task of metadata attribution (within the description wizard), and selects to initiate a submission.
